questions.text:
Ultrasound of a pregnant female showed a snowstorm appearance and enlarged ovaries with theca lutein cysts. She is scheduled to undergo suction and evacuation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Theca lutein cysts do not require specific management apart from suction evacuation of the mole.
She should be followed up at weekly intervals till hCG values become normal.
p57 is strongly expressed in the tissues involved.
She should be advised to use contraception during the follow-up period.

questions.solution:
The USG showing a snowstorm appearance is characteristic of a complete mole. The p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

p57 is used for immunohistochemical staining. It is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed. This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele. Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. The patient presents with a characteristic history of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or spotting, and vomiting during the first trimester. Also, there may be a history of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. On examination, the size of the uterus is larger for gestational age and the fetal heart sounds are absent.

A USG scan shows a snowstorm appearance which is characteristic of a complete mole.

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Hysterectomy is done only if there is uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during surgical evacuation or if the age of the patient is above 35 years and has completed her family.

Serum hCG levels are checked after 48 hours of evacuation and are used as a baseline for future comparisons.

The patient is routinely followed up to watch for the malignant transformation of this condition. During every follow-up visit, a history of irregular vaginal bleeding and breathlessness or hemoptysis is asked for. The abdomen is checked for uterine involution and regression of theca lutein cysts of ovaries. Also, serum or urine hCG is checked at every visit and is compared with the baseline value obtained previously.

Other options -

Option A: Theca lutein cysts usually regress within 2 months of evacuation and hence require no specific or additional management.

Option B: The serum hCG levels are checked every week till it normalizes, which usually takes around 4 to 8 weeks. After the hCG values return to normal, a regular follow-up is done monthly for 6 months. 

Option D: The patient is advised to use contraception to avoid pregnancy during this period as the new pregnancy interferes with the follow-up of hCG values. 

 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presented with difficulty in reading and blurring of vision in both eyes. On evaluation, her visual acuity and fundus examination were normal. Her visual field charting showed a defect as shown below. Where is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown in the image is bitemporal hemianopia. The site of the lesion is the optic chiasma due to the decussation of nasal fibres.

Optic chiasm lesions may produce the following visual field defects

  • Bitemporal hemianopia in case of medial optic chiasm lesions.
  • Binasal hemianopia in case of lateral optic chiasm lesions.

Other notable visual field defects are

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Pie-in-the-sky defects
    • Involvement of Meyer’s loop - inferior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral temporal lobe
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Pie-in-the-floor defects
    • Involvement of Baum’s loop - superior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral parietal lobe
  • Homonymous hemianopia
    • Involvement of retrochiasmal regions such as optic tract, geniculate body, and optic radiations.
    • Sparing of the macula and more congruous field defect (both sides have the same extent of field loss) when the occipital cortex is involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery suddenly developed a temperature of 102 F and a pulse rate of 130 bpm. His capnograph shows the following finding. Your senior resident injects intravenous dantrolene immediately. All the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia managed with intravenous dantrolene. All the above-mentioned drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except calcium channel blockers as they may cause hyperkalemia when used in combination with dantrolene.

The capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in EtCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Dantrolene sodium is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg) till the attack subsides.

Correction of Electrolyte Imbalances:

  • Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  • Hyperkalemia should be treated with insulin.
  • Furosemide may be used to induce diuresis and prevent acute kidney failure.

Other treatment options:

  • All anesthetic agents should be cut off.
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2.
  • If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs, and cooling blankets.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brainstem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH toward normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: An hour after the blood transfusion, the patient develops a fever with chills and flank pain. Tachycardia and hypotension are noted on examination. The direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following mediates this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and is mediated by IgM antibodies.
 
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) occurs within 24 hours of transfusion and is usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The patient presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, fever, flank pain, and in severe cases, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
 
It is caused by ABO incompatibility which is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. They test positive for the direct Coomb's test. In light of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, the transfusion is to be stopped immediately.

Allergic or urticarial reactions during transfusions are mediated by IgE antibodies.

A delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction which occurs after 24 hours (within 2 weeks) of transfusion is a reaction mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever
  • Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
  • Screening of COVID infection among the international passengers at the airport

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests. Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had undergone prolonged surgery in a  prone position with his hip extended. Post-operatively he complained of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the nerve involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of prolonged surgery in prone position with hip extended and symptoms of paresthesia over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

questions.text: A patient underwent emergency surgery for a femoral shaft fracture. On the 2nd post-operative day, he developed fever, breathlessness, and was disoriented. On examination, he had axillary and subconjunctival petechiae. CT pulmonary angiogram showed diffuse patchy ground-glass shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The development of fever, breathlessness, disorientation, and subconjunctival and axillary petechiae within 72 hours of a traumatic skeletal (femur) fracture and CT angiogram showing pulmonary infarction points towards the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome. 

Fat embolism syndrome is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after the fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors:

  • The release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats that causes toxic vasculitis.
  • Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

The early signs of fat embolism syndrome that occur within 72 hours of injury are fever and tachycardia. The presenting features can be classified into 2 types:

  • Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and coma
  • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia

Pathognomic signs include a petechial rash in front of neck/ anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva.

Management of fat embolism is mainly supportive. This consists of respiratory support with high inspired oxygen concentration, heparinization, intravenous low molecular weight dextran, and corticosteroids to reduce the inflammation in the lungs. Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures reduces the incidence of fat embolism syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Hemorrhagic shock is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Option B: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intra-compartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures (commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paresthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressures. Fasciotomy is done in confirmed cases.

Option D: Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery). This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate born at term presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest x-ray of the neonate is shown below. The given congenital heart defect is seen due to the developmental defect of _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the neonate has a cyanotic heart defect and the given x-ray shows figure of 8 or snowman appearance characteristic of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC).

TAPVC refers to a condition in which pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. This results in anomalous drainage of pulmonary venous blood flow into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with features of congestive heart failure. The patients are irritable and have failure to thrive. 

The following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into the superior vena cava or the left innominate vein.
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. It is shown in the image below.

Other options: (Differentials for cyanotic heart disease) 

Option A: Tricuspid valvular defect is seen in Ebstein's anomaly where the valve is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged right atrium resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly giving a box-shape heart appearance. 

Option C: Aorta and pulmonary artery defects are seen in the transposition of great arteries. Here, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle. The x-ray shows cardiomegaly with cardiac contours which appear like an egg on the side. 

Option D: Truncus arteriosus is a single artery arising from the heart. This single artery supplies pulmonary, systemic, and coronary circulation. It is always associated with a VSD. The truncus overrides the defect and receives blood from both the right and left ventricles.

questions.text: A young woman presented to the emergency with epistaxis due to multiple episodes of continuous violent sneezes. To control the bleeding the following technique was performed as shown in the image given below. This method helps her to control bleeding from the septal branches of all of the following arteries, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method. This method helps her to control bleeding from all of the given arteries, except the septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery. 

Trotter's method is a step to control epistaxis from Little’s area. Here, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth and pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery does not take part in the vascular anastomoses seen in this area. Hence, it fails to prevent bleeding from this artery.

Little’s area is situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. Septal branches of four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus. The arteries include:

  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery

Note: Woodruff's plexus is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults. It is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A tourist presented with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a skin lesion as shown below after a forest hike. He remembers getting an insect bite during the forest hike. Which of the following is the causative organism for the above disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of insect bite followed by fever and lymphadenopathy and the clinical image of eschar formation are suggestive of scrub typhus. The causative organism for scrub typhus is O. tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is caused by O. tsutsugamushi and the vector is trombiculid mite. Clinical features include fever, lymphadenopathy, headache, and eschar where the chigger has been fed.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Doxycycline, Azithromycin, or chloramphenicol are also used for the treatment. In the case of pregnant women where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated, azithromycin may be preferred.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, intense pruritus, and weight loss for the past four months. Further evaluation reveals the laboratory findings:
Liver Function Tests Values Normal Range
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 6 0.2-2
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 65 5-30
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 55 5-30
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 450 5-100

His MRCP appears as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about this patient's condition?

choices.text: c-ANCA is a commonly associated antibody in this condition
This patient should be evaluated for the presence of inflammatory bowel disease
Osteoporosis is a complication of advanced disease
The only curative option for this patient is liver transplantation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis and it is commonly associated with p-ANCA antibody, not c-ANCA.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) is characterized by inflammatory strictures involving intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. It eventually leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis. It affects the age group 30–45 years with a male: female ratio of 2:1. It is associated with ulcerative colitis, Riedel’s thyroiditis, and retroperitoneal fibrosis. Patients may also develop cholangiocarcinoma. 

Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

  • Intermittent jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Pruritus
  • Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable. There is hypergammaglobulinemia.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERC) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra and extrahepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management with resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with sclerosing cholangitis with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option that is curative. A long-standing complication of this condition includes osteoporosis, cirrhosis, and cholangiocarcinoma.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

questions.text: A lady diagnosed with breast carcinoma underwent chemotherapy and reports hair loss after two weeks. What is this pattern of hair loss known as?
questions.solution:
Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. 

Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hairs and the condition is called anagen effluvium. The hair loss is acute and diffuse. However, there is full recovery within a few months of stopping the causative drug. 

The most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  1. Anti-microtubule agents (paclitaxel)
  2. Topo-isomerase inhibitors (doxorubicin)
  3. Alkylating agents (cyclophosphamide)
  4. Anti-metabolites (5-fluorouracil)

Other options:

Option A: Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory condition that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is caused by a T‐cell‐mediated autoimmune mechanism. The characteristic initial lesion is a smooth, circum­scribed patch of hair loss. Short, easily extractable broken hairs are seen at the margins of the patch, known as exclamation mark hairs.

Option B: Telogen effluvium refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase. It is an acute‐onset hair loss. It usually occurs 2–3 months following a triggering event such as high fever, surgery, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

Option D: Telogen gravidarum refers to the telogen hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after childbirth.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

questions.text: A young woman presented with mood disturbance, tearfulness, and a lack of energy on the 5th day of postpartum. She was counseled and educated about postpartum blues. She should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last longer than:
questions.solution:
The patient should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last >2 weeks.

Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood and sadness. It typically develops within one week of delivery. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. Treatment is nothing more than education and support, however, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is characterized by a minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation lasting for >2 weeks. It is usually seen within the 4-6 weeks. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby. 

Postpartum psychosis or puerperal psychosis is a psychotic disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. It is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset of 2-3 weeks postpartum although it can occur in the first few days. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by insomnia, restlessness, agitation, lability of mood, and mild cognitive deficits. The treatment of choice involves antipsychotics and lithium, with an antidepressant. 

Postpartum delirium is characterized by fluctuating levels of awareness or attention.

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: You are examining the injuries in a suspected case of homicide. The shape of the stab wound that you notice is depicted in the image below. What type of weapon might have caused this injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a wedge-shaped wound, which is caused by injury with a single-edged knife.

A stab wound occurs when the force is applied into the depths of the body, along the long axis of narrow or pointed weapons like knives, daggers, swords, etc. The depth of the stab wound is more than its length and width.

The size and shape of a stab wound depend on the weapon, the body part that is stabbed, the depth of insertion, angle of withdrawal, the direction of thrust, and the condition of tension or relaxation of the skin. 

The shape of the wound usually corresponds to the weapon used, but the shape of the wounds made by the same weapon may differ on different parts of the body. 

Single-edged weapons cause triangular or wedge-shaped wounds. One angle of the wound will be sharp, while the other will be rounded, blunt, or squared off. If the back edge of the blade is stout, small splits in the skin at the corners of the blunt end of the wound may be seen. These are referred to as fishtailing.

Other options:

Option B - A double-edged knife would produce a slit-like or elliptical wound. Both the edges of the wound are likely to be sharp.

Option C - An ice pick would produce a single small circular wound resembling wounds caused by a small caliber gun.

Option D - A screwdriver would produce a slit-like wound with squared edges.

questions.text: A child is brought to the doctor with severe agonizing, burning pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities. On examination, he also has telangiectatic skin lesions, particularly between the umbilicus and knees. The ophthalmic examination also reveals corneal opacity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism because of deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes. The features of Fabry disease include:

  • Angiokeratomas- telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities (Cornea verticillata)
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent maltese cross

 Given below is the image of cornea verticillata.

Other options

Option B- Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficiency of sphingomyelinase. Affected children exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option C- Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of β-Glucosidase. It commonly has a combination of growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells which have a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

The below image shows Gaucher cells.

Option D- Tay-Sachs disease occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. Hepatosplenomegaly is rare.

Cherry red spots are commonly seen in Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease, generalized gangliosidoses, Niemann-Pick disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, etc

Below image- Cherry red spot

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man had an NSTEMI 3 years ago and was lost to follow-up. He has now presented with dyspnea on exertion and pedal edema. On examination, he has an elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Which of the following drugs is not found to decrease the risk of mortality in him?

NSTEMI: Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction
JVP: Jugular venous pressure
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure secondary to NSTEMI. Digoxin is not found to decrease the risk of mortality in heart failure.

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The important etiologies of heart failure include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, high output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, and severe anemia.

Clinical features of heart failure include dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, pedal edema, anorexia, pallor, elevated JVP, ascites, and hepatomegaly.

Heart failure is classified based on the ejection fraction:

  • Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) - left ventricular ejection fraction is ≥50%
  • Heart failure with mid-range ejection fraction (HFmEF) - left ventricular ejection fraction 40-50%
  • Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrPF) - left ventricular ejection fraction is ≤40%

The mainstay management of heart failure is medical therapy and device therapy is reserved for refractory cases. The type of medications used in medical therapy are:

  • Drugs with symptomatic and mortality benefits provide symptomatic relief and reduce mortality risk by preventing cardiac remodeling. It includes - 
    • Angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) - a combination of sacubitril and valsartan
    • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors - ramipril, enalapril
    • β-blockers - metoprolol, carvedilol, bisoprolol
    • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist - spironolactone, eplerenone
    • Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitor) - dapagliflozin
  • Drugs with only symptomatic benefits provide only symptomatic relief and have no effect on reducing mortality risk. It includes - 
    • Loop diuretics - furosemide
    • Digoxin

Unfortunately, evidence of the clinical benefits of most therapies is restricted to HFrEF. Pharmacological therapy used in HFpEF is mainly diuretics.

Non-pharmacological therapy includes implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD), cardiac resynchronization using biventricular pacing, etc. These treatments are not found to be effective in HFpEF.

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

questions.text: While calculating the ankle-brachial pressure index for patients with peripheral vascular disease using the formula X/systolic pressure of the brachial artery, what is taken as the value of 'X'?

choices.text: Highest of systolic pressure of dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal arteries
One-third of the systolic pressure of dorsalis pedis artery
Two third of the systolic pressure of  posterior tibial artery
Sum of systolic pressures of peroneal and dorsalis pedis arteries

questions.solution:
The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery. The brachial systolic pressure in the ipsilateral arm is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >0.9 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Claudication
  • <0.5 – Rest pain
  • <0.4 – Imminent necrosis (Critical Limb Ischemia)

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) - 

PAD presents as intermittent claudication, which is pain that increases with walking and may sometimes present with rest pain. It is generally caused by atherosclerosis but may also be due to trauma. The initial investigation done is an ABPI. Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

 

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: An unimmunized child developed a fever, cough, and conjunctival congestion. 4 days later he developed a rash behind his ears which soon became widespread as shown in the image below. On examination, bluish-white spots were seen on the inner aspect of the cheek. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

choices.text: Myocarditis is the most common cause of death
Hemorrhagic form of the disease is often fatal
Low levels of retinol is associated with increased  mortality
Acute otitis media is the most common complication

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing a morbilliform rash are suggestive of measles. The incorrect statement about the complication related to this condition is that myocarditis is the most common cause of death. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death in measles. 

Pneumonia in measles can be giant cell pneumonia which is caused by the virus directly or can be due to superadded bacterial infection.

Measles infection is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA Paramyxovirus. It has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. These spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of the premolars.

A maculopapular rash appears 4 days after fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash. The morbilliform rash is shown below. 

The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. Sinusitis and mastoiditis are also seen. Black measles or hemorrhagic measles is a fatal complication characterized by hemorrhagic skin eruptions. It is rarely seen nowadays. Other complications include croup, tracheitis, bronchiolitis, diarrhea and vomiting, febrile seizures, and encephalitis. Myocarditis is a rare complication of measles.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare but fatal complication characterized by cognitive decline, spasticity of limbs, and seizures. It is insidious in onset and clinical manifestations usually begin 7-10 years after primary measles infection. It is caused due to persistent infection with a genetically altered variant of the measles virus within the central nervous system.

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells. The image below shows a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell. 

Low serum retinol levels in children with measles are associated with higher morbidity and mortality and hence Vitamin A therapy is indicated for all patients with measles. The management is mainly supportive. There is no role for antivirals.

questions.solution:
Warfarin acts by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase.

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome (due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion), and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in newborns. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab
